data.title: Add atom.workspace to all specs
data.body: This is in preparation for moving the opener functionality from project to workspace. Since we add atom.project to every spec, it also makes sense that atom.workspace should be there as well.

data.title: Paste with formatting
data.body:
When I paste a snippet of code that has indentation I want my editor to be smart enough to correctly indent things for me.
### Example 1

Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/clipboard.coffee
2. Copy some indented text but on the first line just go to the beginning of the text, not the beginning of the line
3. Paste the text into Atom at an indentation level different than what it should be indented at

![](http://cl.ly/image/3G1A3u3P043a/paste.gif)
### Example 2

When you go across windows it loses the indentation magic.

![](http://cl.ly/image/1R0T2J0j111z/paste2.gif)

It can get pretty noisy, but I think this will be helpful as we rev the API.

data.title: Support native browser copy operation for non-editor text
data.body:
People expect to be able to copy selected text from subclasses of `ScrollView`. We could suggest they always use the `native!` binding, but I think we can do better. I can think of two options:
1. Copy text based on the current browser-level selection when a copy command reaches the top of the workspace.
2. Invoke the browser's native copy behavior when a copy command reaches the root of the workspace.

data.title: Add keymaps for modules on Linux
Upgrade to atom-shell@0.11.5
data.body: Upgrade to atom-shell@0.11.5 which fixed a few Linux related problems.

data.title: Oh man, the GC pausing
data.body:
I built just now (8pm pacific apr 1), and I am getting crazy painful gc pausing. Last time I built was probably early last week.
- 275 line md file with code blocks, soft wrapped
- markdown preview

What I see: 
- Often typing is choppy due to a pause.
- Often scrolling is laggy due to a pause.

I tried to do the heap timeline, but when I did, I had no gc pauses. Fuuuu. I'm going to leave it on for the duration of my usage, and see if I can catch one.

data.title: Linux tweaks
data.body: Addresses some things in #1814

data.title: 'l' in vim mode opens web inspector
data.body:
Doesn't happen on all files all the time, but seems to happen pretty consistently on this one [markdown file I'm editing](https://gist.githubusercontent.com/d2fn/22663b374a26a9609282/raw/29e9a09c9ff8d4bdc8dc832b70c9714e5381537d/gistfile1.txt). 

NB: I have soft wrap turned on and the markdown preview window open when this happens.

cc #1815

data.title: Let's go full harmony!
data.body:
I was going to try and write a package in pure ES6 and wanted to use more of the harmony features v8 gives.

Using the --harmony flag gives us all of the harmony functionality and it didn't affect start time (~1360ms for both) or spec run time (~1:10 for both).

data.body:
Notice the left `'` is over the border of the gutter

![screen shot 2014-04-01 at 2 20 02 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/671378/2584835/72625dfa-b9e3-11e3-9a88-22c48470c80a.png)

data.title: 'j' often doesn't work for vim binding
data.body:
Hitting `j` doesn't move down a line. Just does nothing.

Seems to be sensitive to the file being used. I seem to be able to reproduce this any type of file but not consistently. Have to use the down arrow or ctrl+n to move down a line. No visible clues in the console.

data.title: Linux ship list
data.body:
Items to complete before shipping a preview release on Linux, tested on Ubuntu LTS 12.04 64-bit.
### Issues
- Had to run `sudo apt-get install libgnome-keyring-dev` before being able to build keytar.
### TODO
- [x] `apm ls` doesn't list bundled packages
- [x] `oniguruma` not building due to `OnigRegExp::Search` return value compiler error.
- [x] `atom` binary was not executable in `atom-shell/atom` or `/usr/local/share/atom/atom` after `script/build` and `sudo script/grunt install`
- [x] Fix keybinding issues https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/pull/10
- [x] Fix `tab` key not working by itself https://github.com/atom/atom-shell/issues/221
- [ ] Draft blog post
- [ ] :ship:

data.title: “Unknown stream file type” error on launch
data.body:
I get the following error “Error: Implement me. Unknown stream file type!” on launch, I saw this in 0.80.0 and 0.81.0.

![screen shot 2014-03-31 at 17 04 30](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22101/2577889/699c8b36-b985-11e3-98e9-883897eebf31.png)

This occurs when launching from Finder or from the `atom` command line helper.

The application is non functional after this error :cry:.

/cc #1333

data.title: Refer to files containing key bindings as keymaps instead of the global
data.body:
Previously, we referred to the global that contains all the key bindings as the "keymap". But there are folders in our packages called `keymaps/`, implying that these files are called keymaps. It's confusing to have one global thing called keymap that contains a bunch of smaller things that are _also_ called keymaps.

Instead, this PR updates `atom.keymap` to become `atom.keymaps` and the class to be called `KeymapManager`. Methods have been renamed to enforce the idea that files containing bindings are called keymaps.

I've left `atom.keymap` in place as a deprecated property. I'd like to merge this so I can publish the blog post and then start working on a deprecation mechanism that we can use to keep track of where we are using deprecated code paths.

data.title: Double slash sequence triggers errors in .c files
data.body:
Halp ticket: support/55dbd394b77e11e38c032c4d97cee107

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a file named test.c with the following content:
   
   ``` c
   #include foo.c
   
   int main()
   {
     int a;
   }
   ```
2. Open the file in Atom
3. Position the cursor above the `int main()` line
4. Press `/` twice

The first `/` goes through just fine, but the second `/` triggers an error shown in Console:

```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'c' of undefined /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/node_modules/scoped-property-store/lib/selector.js:77
```

data.title: Atom cannot open a github/Windows clone
data.body:
I saw logs of the form `31/03/2014 14:13:36.000 kernel[0]: file: table is full` when attempting to open the repository in Atom.

I ran `sudo fs_usage` and saw `Atom Helper.app` opening thousands of file descriptors for the objects in the repository.

**Steps to Reproduce**
1. Clone https://github.com/github/Windows on OS X
2. Launch Atom, I’m using Version 0.80.0
3. Run `sudo fs_usage`
4. Drag the directory github/Windows is cloned into onto the Atom icon

**Expected Results**

The workspace opens quickly.

**Actual Results**

System failure as the kernel’s global file table is exhausted O_O

data.title: Atom should not set itself as the default editor without asking
data.body:
Halp tickets:
- support/7a8136c2b36d11e390226cf1a8939a7f
- support/84d1eb7eb81f11e3887061e8dcc03c4b

> Atom should not set itself as the default editor without asking which it did.

...

> For it to have grabbed the default file association of a great many file types is inconvenient, to say the least. Please make this a preference.

data.title: Proxy settings are not respected in some places
data.body:
Noticed two Halp tickets about this so far:
- support/a10f96d4b08f11e3934b3dfc0d230d46
- support/45b5441aa86911e39c8bef69aceed9d5

> Finally, I didn't find any way to set my proxy info in the settings of your app, and I'm not sure you are respecting the proxy settings of the OS. So my first attempt to send feedback failed.

...

> I tried to submit this via the built-in feedback but it didn't say it was successful, it seemed to time out just like fetching packages or themes:
> Built-in package and theme fetching doesn't work when proxies are required. "Fetching featured packages and themes failed. connect ENETUNREACH". DNS resolves on this corporate network, but connections must use http or https proxies.
> Self-updating Atom itself works.

So, it seems that proxy settings are not respected, and it's not possible to set them in Atom.

data.title: Support for non-UTF-8 encodings
data.body:
We've received a few user requests about this, so decided to make an issue to track this:
- support/c1efbd22aac011e3824485c02873dc32#C3
- support/6026ed1eb23511e39be96d50cc8424ad
- support/4ab67e5aaf6411e388d6c56073fdae1e

> The editor can only reads UTF-8 files. It will be very handy to be able to support multiple encodings.

...

> I need to change the encode of my code, but I cant find where I could change from UTF-8 for Windows 1252 for example.

data.title: Errors should open the devtools with the Console tab selected
data.body:
Halp ticket:
- support/5f8b9d7eb38d11e39432007c4439fcd9

> Is there a way to have it on console tab in developer tools automatically when an error appears?

I think this is a great idea. Currently, the devtools are shown whenever an error happens, but it's not clear to the users that an error happened because the Console tab was not selected:

![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2560788/81490d52-b7e3-11e3-8797-76266a053d46.gif)

Would it be possible to select the Console tab automatically in these situations?

data.title: Can't shell out with BufferedProcess
data.body: I was working on a package and couldn't get git to run via BufferedProcess, so I just used child_proces. Then I installed this package: https://atom.io/packages/merge-conflicts and it failed with ENOENT trying to use BufferedProcess as well. @probablycorey ran into the same thing with his linter package. Is there something about my machine / our machines (boxen-related?) that is different than the general public that might be breaking BufferedProcess?

data.title: Fix case insensitive issues with Git
data.body:
`atom.project.getPath()` can sometimes not equal `atom.project.getRepo().getWorkingDirectory()` since libgit2 always provides the path is the case on disk while `atom.project.getPath()` may differ in case to the path on disk on case insensitive filesystems.

Most of the fixes will be in underlying libraries to handle this but a few bundled packages need updating.
- [x] Update status-bar
- [x] Update tree-view
- [x] Update fuzzy-finder
### New Public APIs
- `Git::getCachedPathStatus(path)` - This replaces using `atom.project.getRepo().statuses` directly by adding an API that properly relativizes paths since statuses are now stored relative to the repository root to prevent casing problems.

data.title: Add `core.followSymbolicLinks`
data.body:
People are adding symbolic link functionality to individual packages [1](https://github.com/atom/find-and-replace/pull/167) [2](https://github.com/atom/fuzzy-finder/pull/13#issuecomment-36799709).

I think it makes more sense to add this option to core. `project.scan` would be able to use this and other packages could query the config option.

data.body:
Reported in Halp:

> Atom Helper process spawns become out of control and appear to not be closing out properly ( even after closing tabs, windows, and atom iteself). My system was becoming extremely sluggish, and i looked at the processes and saw this
> http://imgur.com/EZazOPG
> This was AFTER i had QUIT atom on the mac. If you double clicked on one of those processes, it would show a parent process as null(xxxx)

And the followup:

> Yes, it appears to be happening quite frequently (versions I had were .73 and now .78). Here is a screenshot showing the null pid http://i.imgur.com/3KCpzal.png.
> I even quit out of Atom and let it sit for an hour while at lunch and it still didn't kill any of the processes. I am running a regular macbook pro mid 2012 osx 10.9.2 2.5ghz i5 16gb 1600mhz ddr3

![3kcpzal](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/2552224/111085f8-b697-11e3-9860-ddbf12533530.png)

data.title: Certain CSS classes in syntax tokens cause issues
data.body:
Reported in https://github.com/atom/highlights/issues/2

Having a token with a `close` scope generates a `.close` class which makes the text render incorrectly since Bootstrap defined a `.close` class for dialogs.

data.title: Calculate invisibles correctly
data.body: Previously the cursor position could get f'd up because of leading whitespace. This happened if invisibles were turned on and the invisible character was a different size that the actual character. This PR fixes all that.

data.title: CSS selectors are insufficient replacements for TextMate scope selectors
data.body:
We've borrowed TextMate's scope selector concept, but since we're a web-based editor, we've gone with CSS syntax rather than TextMate's proprietary scope selector syntax to blend in with the web.

Unfortunately, CSS on its own doesn't fully support the concept of a scope. CSS is focused on identifying _individual_ elements, whereas scope selectors are focused on identifying _subtrees_ of the document, which could include multiple elements.

We've attempted to encode TextMate's `-` operator using `:not` pseudoclasses, but it falls down. Say we're describing the following TextMate scope in CSS:

```
text.html .meta.tag - entity.other.attribute-name
```

This basically says, I want this to match inside HTML tags, _except_ for inside attribute names. We attempt to translate it to the following incorrect CSS selector:

```
.text.html .meta.tag:not(.entity.other.attribute-name)
```

Say we're matching against the following scope chain:

```
.text.html .meta.tag .entity.other.attribute-name
```

We first try matching the `attribute-name`, which fails because no selector matches, so we pop it. Then we try to match the `meta.tag`, and this _does_ match, regardless of the negation.

So you see that TextMate's `-` operator really can't be encoded with negation. It's operating on subtrees, whereas `:not` operates on individual elements.

data.title: Flicker when switching tabs
data.body:
Seems to only happen when switching to a single tab in this gif.

![white-flicker](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/671378/2515147/b97f6b9a-b440-11e3-8c46-d67d6b2d48fe.gif)
